string.name: addplant_eggplant_mini_desc
string.p: Commonly used as a vegetable in dishes, but is, scientifically, actually, a fruit. The plant is one of the many vegetables you can grow in your garden, however, it is very sensitive to cold. Raw eggplant is composed of 92% water, 6% carbs, and 1% protein.

string.name: addplant_kamote_mini_desc
string.p: A root vegetable grown in tropical and subtropical regions worldwide that contains various Vitamins and Minerals, making it the second most important root crop grown globally (after cassava).

resources.string: The sweet potato is a dicotyledonous plant that belongs to the bindweed or morning glory family, Convolvulaceae. Its large, starchy, sweet-tasting, tuberous roots are a root vegetable. Throughout Asia, people process sweet potato for snacks such as chips or animal feeds. Its tubers contain carbohydrates, protein, sodium), Vitamin A, Vitamin C, and calcium. Sweet potato is rich in dietary fiber, calcium, complex carbohydrates, and antioxidants.

string.name: mats_eggplant_desc
string.p: The fruit is widely used in cooking. As a member of the genus Solanum, it is related to the tomato and the potato. Eggplant is one of the many vegetables you can grow in your garden, but the plant is very sensitive to cold. Raw eggplant is composed of 92% water, 6% carbohydrates, 1% protein, and negligible fat.

Growing your slips (Day 0) \n\t1. Clean the sweet potato and split it in half (or large sections).
\t2. Put them in a container with half of the potato submerged in water.
\t3. Put it in a window ledge or anywhere warm (e.g. on top of a radiator).
\t4. Observe if the slips are 6-9 inches long everyday within the first 6 weeks of planting.
\t5. Twist the slips off from the potato
\t6. Transfer the slip to a shallow bowl with half the stem submerged in water.
\t7. Observe if the roots have grown about an inch and keep the water fresh (few days).
Transferring the Slips \n\t8. Make sure the soil is loose

\t9. Using a small hand trowel, dig a hole about 4" or 5" deep and 3" wide. Place one slip in each hole with the roots pointing down. Position the slip so that the bottom halfwill be covered with dirt while the top half with all of the new leaves is above ground.
\t10. Carefully cover the hole with soil and gently press (to remove remaining air pockets).
Growing the potatoes \n\t11. Water until the surrounding dirt is wet. Stop watering before your mound starts to erode.
\t15. Water at least once a week (70-150 days).
\t16. Check the soil everyday. Water the soil if it is dry.
Harvesting \n\t17. Observe if leaves start to yellow(everyday).
\t18. Use a spading fork to dig tubers on a sunny day when the soil is dry.
2. Prepare soil. Mix 2 parts potting soil, 1 part sand. Mix a little compost and 5-10-5 fertilizer.
4. Start indoors, temperature must be 12.8 C or higher. Fill your small pots or trays with the potting mix.
5. Poke a ½ inch (1.25 cm) hole in the center of each pot or tray. Place 2 seeds in each hole. Cover them afterwards, just lightly drop the soil over the seeds, don’t pack it in.
6. Set the pots or trays out on a warm, sunny windowsill. Ensure that the window receives at least 8 hours of sunlight a day.
7. Water the seeds every day. Don’t create puddles of water on top of your soil but prevent the soil from drying out.
8. Once the seedlings sprout two sets of leaves, snip out the weaker seedling, do not yank the weaker seedling out.
9. Prepare for transplanting once the plant reaches at least ½ foot (15.25 cm) in height.
10. Set up the supporting stakes in the permanent pot.
11. Fill the permanent pot with the potting medium
12. Dig a hole in the center of the pot that is as deep and wide as the container the seedlings are currently planted in.
13. Remove the seedling from its container and place it into the new pot. It is easier to transplant a wet and compact soil than dry, crumbly soil.
14. Place the pot in a sunny location.
15. Water the plant daily. You might need to water additionally if the weather is hot and dry
16. Add liquid fertilizer once every 2 weeks. Make sure you add fertilizer after watering the soil, don’t add fertilizer on dry soil.
17. Tie the eggplant to the support to promote upward growth.
19. Harvest when the skin looks glossy.

\tPlantEEEI is an app that would assist its users, especially beginners, in planting. It would provide information on a number of species of plants and steps on taking care of the said species of plants among other things.
\n\n\tThe app aims to encourage people to plant and/or grow fruits and vegetables, which can be used for their own consumption, to promote a greener household environment and, also, possibly, a better state of physical and mental health.
\tThe Developer team consists of four members, all currently taking BS Computer Engineering as their degree program in the University of the Philippines-Diliman.
